context.name: ServiceControlProxy
context.description: This level is used to view and modify Service Control Proxy-related attributes. The Intelligent Network Service Control (INSC) allows legacy Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN) subscribers to use a subset of BroadWorks services. BroadWorks acts as an off-board extension of a Service Control Point (SCP) thereby allowing calls from the PSTN to be served by BroadWorks. For the INSC, Service Control Points (SCPs) inter-work Advanced Intelligent Network (AIN) triggers to an XML-based protocol interface, which is called the Wholesale Protocol (WSP). This protocol is based on the BroadWorks Client Application Protocol (CAP) interface. The Network Server provides a single point of contact for an SCP into BroadWorks. To do this the Network Server performs the following functions, which are referred to as the SCP. The Network Server communicates with the SCP using WSP messages over HTTP. The Network Server hides the details of Application Server redundancy mechanisms from the SCP and distributes requests from the SCP to the hosting Application Server cluster. The Network Server communicates these requests to the Application Server using WSP over TCP/IP sockets. To provide service control, WSP ServiceRequest messages, carried over HTTP, are forwarded over TCP to the Application Server. ServiceAction responses received through the TCP are also relayed back to the requesting SCP over HTTP. The Service Control Proxy handles the function between the SCP, on the client side, and the Application Server, on the server side. The Service Control Proxy is collocated with the Network Server. The Network Server is used to look up the Application Server address based on the provided subscriber DN. SCP IP addresses are validated against the Service Control Proxy Access Control List, which is used to restrict access from unknown SCPs. The Service Control Proxy level is used to enter SCP IP addresses from which CAP/HTTP messages are honored.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the list of allowed IP addresses from which HTTP traffic is processed.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add new IP addresses to the Network Control List.

parameter.name: address
parameter.description: The IP address, host name, or domain for the SCP.

parameter.name: description
parameter.description: A description for the IP address, host name, or domain.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify IP addresses on the Network Control List.

parameter.name: address
parameter.description: The IP address, host name, or domain for the SCP.

parameter.name: description
parameter.description: A description for the IP address, host name, or domain.

command.name: delete
command.description: This command is used to delete an IP address from the Network Control List.

parameter.name: address
parameter.description: The IP address, host name, or domain for the SCP.

parameter.name: description
parameter.description: A description for the IP address, host name, or domain.

context.name: OverloadControls
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Network internal (non-configurable) overload controls that manage the internal queues based on size and delay. In overload, the Network Server sheds requests in the queue without responding to the source. The Network Server also provides transaction-based server licensing that can be enabled to return a 503 response when the transactions per second have surpassed the licensed value. The Network Server also supports configurable Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) overload control mechanisms. They allow the Network Server to remain in service despite being flooded with incoming SIP messages. Therefore, until the overload condition goes away, the Network Server tries to take action to remain in service. This means that:When the Network Server detects that it enters into light overload (called yellow zone), it no longer tries to process all incoming transactions. For the incoming SIP messages that are not processed while in the yellow zone, depending on provisioning, the Network Server either silently drops the message or responds with a SIP 503 "Service Unavailable" message. The feature includes an enhanced optional overload mechanism whereby Network Elements (NEs) that seem to contribute the most to the overload condition are throttled first. If the amount of incoming messages is such that the actions taken in the yellow zone do not help the Network Server recover, the Network Server enters the major overload zone: the red zone. In this state, the Network Server discards or refuses (with the use of 503's - if so provisioned) all new transactions. Emergency calls are still processed, if the Network Server is provisioned as such. Depending on provisioning, the 503 responses that the Network Server sends may or may not contain the Retry-After header. The use of this header allows the Network Server to better throttle Network Elements (NEs) that seem to be the major cause of the overload. This is because a Network Element (NE) receiving a 503 with Retry-After is not supposed to send new messages to the Network Server for the amount of time specified in the''Retry-After''header.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the overload control-related attributes.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify the overload control-related attributes.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to modify.

parameter.name: enabled
parameter.description: Specifies whether overload controls are enabled or not.

parameter.name: percentMemoryInUseToEnterYellow
parameter.description: The amount (%) of processor memory (heap) in use that when exceeded causes the Network Server to enter the yellow zone.

parameter.name: percentMemoryInUseToEnterRed
parameter.description: The amount (%) of processor memory (heap) in use that when exceeded causes the Network Server to enter the red zone.

parameter.name: percentMemoryInUseToLeaveYellow
parameter.description: The processor memory usage has to go down to this level (%) before the Network Server can return to return to the green zone.

parameter.name: percentMemoryInUseToLeaveRed
parameter.description: The processor memory usage has to go down to this level (%) before the Network Server can return to return to the yellow zone.

parameter.name: sipOverloadAction
parameter.description: The action the Network Server should take for dropped messages in case of overload: either silently drop the message or respond with the SIP 503 "Service Unavailable" message.

parameter.name: allowEmergencyCallsInOverload
parameter.description: Determines whether emergency calls will be processed during overload.

parameter.name: maxPacketAgeInMsecs
parameter.description: The maximum allowed age of a message in a decode queue.

parameter.name: maxPacketAgeDuringOverloadInMsecs
parameter.description: The maximum allowed age of a message in a decode queue during overload.

parameter.name: supportCongestionManagement
parameter.description: Specifies whether the Retry-After support and the related congestion algorithm is enabled or disabled. To enable this, the Overload Controls should also be enabled, the sipOverloadAction configuration parameter should be set to "error", and the supportCongestionManagement configuration parameter should be set to "true".

parameter.name: minRetryAfterInSeconds
parameter.description: Specifies the minimum time that the neighboring Network Element (NE) has to wait before sending messages to the Network Server. The Retry-After header value included in the SIP 503 Retry-After header, sent to the neighboring NE in response to a dropped message, is a number selected randomly from the range between this and the maxRetryAfterInSeconds values (effective only if the supportCongestionManagement option is set to "true").

parameter.name: maxRetryAfterInSeconds
parameter.description: Specifies the maximum time that the neighboring Network Element (NE) has to wait before sending messages to the Network Server. The Retry-After header value included in the SIP 503 Retry-After header, sent to the neighboring NE in response to a dropped message, is a number selected randomly from the range between this and the minRetryAfterInSeconds values (effective only if the supportCongestionManagement option is set to "true").

parameter.name: trafficSamplingPeriodInSeconds
parameter.description: The time period, in seconds, over which the traffic is sampled to determine traffic load and detect overload condition.

parameter.name: aggregateQueueMonitoring
parameter.description: Enables monitoring using an aggregate of data from the processing queues, versus each queue separately.

context.name: CallP
context.description: This level is used to view or change Call Processing (CallP) Overload Control-related attributes.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view Call Processing (CallP) overload control-related attributes.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify Call Processing (CallP) overload control-related attributes.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to modify.

parameter.name: sampleSize
parameter.description: The size of the rolling window of samples used to determine delays in call processing queues.

parameter.name: minTimeInZoneInMsecs
parameter.description: The minimum amount of time that the Network Server has to stay in a zone before going back to the next lower zone.

parameter.name: delayInMsecsToEnterYellow
parameter.description: The delay in the SIP call decode queue and call processing input adapters, in milliseconds, that when exceeded, causes the Network Server to enter the yellow zone for call processing traffic.

parameter.name: delayInMsecsToEnterRed
parameter.description: The delay in the SIP call decode queue and call processing input adapters, in milliseconds, that when exceeded, causes the Network Server to enter the red zone for call processing traffic.

parameter.name: delayInMsecsToLeaveYellow
parameter.description: When the delay in the SIP call decode queue and call processing input adapters falls below this threshold level, the Network Server is eligible to transition to the green overload zone for call processing traffic.

parameter.name: delayInMsecsToLeaveRed
parameter.description: When the delay in the SIP call decode queue and call processing input adapters falls below this threshold level, the Network Server is eligible to transition to the yellow overload zone for call processing traffic.

context.name: ManagedNeighbors
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the managed neighbours. In the context of the Network Server, a Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) neighbor is defined as being a routing Network Element (NE) or hosting NE address defined.

context.name: Capabilities
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the managed neighbors capabilities-related attributes. Managed neighbors' capability parameters are used to store manually-set capability parameters for all provisioned hosting NE and routing NE addresses.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the managed neighbors capabilities-related attributes.

parameter.name: ipAddress
parameter.description: The managed neighbor's IP address.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify the managed neighbors capabilities-related attributes.

parameter.name: ipAddress
parameter.description: The managed neighbor's IP address.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to modify.

parameter.name: retryAfterReceiver
parameter.description: Specifies whether the neighbor has a Retry-After receiver.

context.name: States
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the managed neighbors states-related attributes. Note that the list contains all routing Network Element (NE) and hosting NE IP addresses provisioned.'''NOTE''': The inService state is a manual state used to force an IP address to remain in service during an overload condition and prevents it from being throttled by congestion management.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the managed neighbors states-related attributes.

parameter.name: ipAddress
parameter.description: The managed neighbor's IP address.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify the managed neighbors states-related attributes.

parameter.name: ipAddress
parameter.description: The managed neighbor's IP address.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to modify.

parameter.name: inService
parameter.description: Specifies whether the neighbor is in a normal condition. Note that when the inService parameter is set to "true", the inhibited parameter cannot be set to "true".

parameter.name: inhibited
parameter.description: Specifies whether the neighbor's traffic flow must be controlled. Note that when the inhibited parameter is set to "true", the inService parameter cannot be set to "true".

context.name: NonCallP
context.description: This level is used to view and modify non-Call Processing (CallP) overload control-related attributes.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view non-Call Processing (CallP) overload control-related attributes.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify non-Call Processing (CallP) overload control-related attributes.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to modify.

parameter.name: sampleSize
parameter.description: The size of the rolling window of samples used to determine delays in non-call processing decode queues and input adapters.

parameter.name: minTimeInZoneInMsecs
parameter.description: The minimum amount of time that the Network Server has to stay in a zone for non-call processing traffic before transitioning to a lower level zone.

parameter.name: delayInMsecsToEnterYellow
parameter.description: The delay in the SIP non-call decode queue and call processing input adapters, in milliseconds, that when exceeded, causes the Network Server to enter the yellow zone for non-call processing traffic.

parameter.name: delayInMsecsToEnterRed
parameter.description: The delay in the SIP non-call decode queue and call processing input adapters, in milliseconds, that when exceeded, causes the Network Server to enter the red zone for non-call processing traffic.

parameter.name: delayInMsecsToLeaveYellow
parameter.description: When the delay in the SIP non-call decode queue and call processing input adapters falls below this threshold level, the Network Server is eligible to transition to the green overload zone for non-call processing traffic.

parameter.name: delayInMsecsToLeaveRed
parameter.description: When the delay in the SIP non-call decode queue and call processing input adapters falls below this threshold level, the Network Server is eligible to transition to the yellow overload zone for non-call processing traffic.

parameter.name: callpQDelayInMsecsToEnterYellow
parameter.description: The delay in the SIP call processing decode queue and call processing input adapters, in milliseconds, that when exceeded, causes the Network Server to enter the yellow zone for non-call processing traffic.

parameter.name: callpQDelayInMsecsToEnterRed
parameter.description: The delay in the SIP call processing decode queue and call processing input adapters, in milliseconds, that when exceeded, causes the Network Server to enter the red zone for non-call processing traffic.

parameter.name: callpQDelayInMsecsToLeaveYellow
parameter.description: When the delay in the SIP call decode processing queue and call processing input adapters falls below this threshold level, the Network Server is eligible to transition from the yellow to the green overload zone for non-call processing traffic.

parameter.name: callpQDelayInMsecsToLeaveRed
parameter.description: When the delay in the SIP call decode processing queue and call processing input adapters falls below this threshold level, the Network Server is eligible to transition from the red to the yellow overload zone for non-call processing traffic.

context.name: Peering
context.description: This level is used to view and modify Network Server peer-related attributes. The Network Server database is replicated to all Network Servers in the network for redundancy. Network Servers are defined for peering, and replication can be started and stopped. The status of replication can also be displayed. Replication configuration can be complex, as the values returned by the get command only represent the desired replication configuration, not the actual one. Desired versus actual configuration: It is important to note, the values returned by the get command, may not reflect the actual state of replication. These values only reflect the desired replication configuration. Likewise, using the add command does not automatically add a server to the replication process. It only informs the Network Server that this server should be added next time replication is started. To effectively synchronize the actual view and the desired view, the operator should stop and then restart replication. Note that during this short interval, the Network Server could theoretically lose replication records. This limitation will be eliminated in an upcoming release. Stopping replication: If two Network Servers, for example NS01 and NS02 are replicated and replication is stopped on NS01, NS02 does not know and still tries to send NS01 replication updates. NS01 is assumed to be down and these updates are buffered on NS02. Eventually, the updates buffer fills and NS02 does not accept any more database modifications until communication is restored with NS01. Therefore, when removing a Network Server from the replication scheme, it is important to stop and restart replication on every server that had a replication relation to it. Masters versus slaves: Masters accept database modifications (provisioning) whereas slaves do not. Use of slaves facilitates maintenance and reduces network traffic. Facilitating maintenance: Unlike masters, slaves need to know only about masters in their own cluster (specifically, they need not to know about masters or slaves in other clusters).Reducing network traffic: Two geographically distant clusters would have their masters propagate replication updates to the slaves, thus reducing network traffic. Hostnames: TimesTen requires that hostnames be limited to 1 to 80 characters; characters are limited to any combination of letters (A-Z), digits (0-9), $, #, @, _. The first character must be a letter. If the hostname is longer than 80 characters, an alias can be created in the /etc/hosts file.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view Network Server peer-related attributes including the peer type and host name. "NOTE": When configuring replication, it is important to use the canonical host name of the server (which can be obtained by typing the hostname command without arguments). Using the IP address or an alias causes replication to fail due to a TimesTen limitation.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify Network Server peer-related attributes.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to modify.

parameter.name: replicationPort
parameter.description: Sets the replication port to a random number.

parameter.name: portOption
parameter.description: When set to "random", the database dynamically pick up a replication port above 32768. When set to "port", allows an operator to specify the replication port to use.

parameter.name: port
parameter.description: Indicator that a replication port is to be configured.

parameter.name: portNumber
parameter.description: Sets the replication port to the specified port number.

command.name: lock
command.description: This command is used to lock the Network Server database. The Network Server database can be locked to prevent any changes from being made to the Network Server. The database can be locked to perform maintenance-related activities such as performing an upgrade. Only masters can be locked. Slaves are always locked; therefore locking/unlocking a slave peer will have no effect.

parameter.name: hostname
parameter.description: The canonical host name of a peer Network Server; if no hostname is provided the current server is assumed.

command.name: start
command.description: The replication process of the Network Server database is started using this command. Database replication will be made to all Network Servers currently existing as a peer Network Server in the network. Whenever there is a change to a Network Server database in the network, the changes are replicated dynamically to all other Network Servers.

command.name: status
command.description: This command is used to view the status of the Network Server database replication. The message field "Replication Agent Policy" will be "Always" if the replication is running.

command.name: stop
command.description: This command is used to stop the replication process of the Network Server database (for example, for replacement). Replication will only begin again once it has been started. Any changes made during the time the replication process has been stopped will not be replicated once the process has started again. The message field "Replication Manually Started" will be "False" if the manual replication has stopped.

command.name: unlock
command.description: This command is used to unlock the Network Server database (to allow changes to be made to the Network Server).

parameter.name: hostname
parameter.description: The canonical host name of the peer Network Server; if no hostname is provided the current server is assumed. Specifying "all" as a hostname will unlock all peers.

context.name: Peers
context.description: This level is used to display Network Server peer-related attributes and to add or delete a Network Server peer.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view peer Network Server-related attributes including the peer type and host name using this command. "NOTE": When configuring replication, it is important to use the canonical host name of the server. The canonical host name can be obtained by typing the hostname command without arguments. Note, however, that using the IP address or an alias causes replication to fail because of a TimesTen limitation.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add a new peer Network Server.

parameter.name: hostname
parameter.description: The canonical host name of the new peer Network Server; if the hostname is longer than 80 characters, an alias can be created in the /etc/hosts file.

parameter.name: address
parameter.description: The routable address of the peer Network Server.

command.name: delete
command.description: This command is used to delete the peer Network Servers. The unique host name is used to delete the associated record. Peer Network Servers are not immediately deleted from the replication process. They are removed when replication is stopped and restarted.

parameter.name: hostname
parameter.description: The canonical host name of the peer Network Server; if the hostname is longer than 80 characters, an alias can be created in the /etc/hosts file.

context.name: RemoteCluster
context.description: This level is used to view or modify the remote cluster attributes.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the remote cluster attributes.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to configure the remote cluster attributes.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to modify.

parameter.name: remoteClusterMaster
parameter.description: This parameter controls whether the remote cluster is the master cluster.

context.name: Peers
context.description: This level is used to display, add, modify or delete a Network Server Remote Cluster peer.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the Network Servers in the remote cluster.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add Network Servers to the remote cluster.

parameter.name: ipAddress
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the corresponding IP address for the Network Server in the remote cluster.

parameter.name: preferred
parameter.description: This parameter controls whether the Network Server is preferred.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify the Network Server related attributes on the remote cluster.

parameter.name: ipAddress
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the corresponding IP address for the Network Server in the remote cluster.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to modify.

parameter.name: preferred
parameter.description: This parameter controls whether the Network Server is preferred.

command.name: delete
command.description: This command is used to delete a Network Server from the remote cluster.

parameter.name: ipAddress
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the corresponding IP address for the Network Server in the remote cluster.

context.name: ProfileTuning
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the profile tuning for the server.

context.name: GeneralSettings
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the general settings of profile tuning.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to get the last applied profile tuning name.

command.name: apply
command.description: This command is used to apply a specific tuning profile. The printed output lists the difference between the current values stored within the configuration and the new values that will be set by applying the profile.

parameter.name: profileTuningName
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the name of the selected profile tuning.

command.name: describe
command.description: This command is used to print the configuration changes performed by a profile. The printed output lists the difference between the current values stored within the configuration and the new values that would be set by applying the profile. No configuration changes are applied.

parameter.name: profileTuningName
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the name of the selected profile tuning.

context.name: Resources
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the physical resources of the server.

context.name: Memory
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the memory allocation rules for the applications running on the server.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to show memory allocation general settings. They include the over-allocation protection, which will adjust the container memory allocation if the configured memory settings exceed physical memory available.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to set memory allocation general settings.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to modify.

parameter.name: overAllocationProtection
parameter.description: This parameter controls whether the software manager adjusts the containers memory allocation if the configured memory settings exceed the physical memory available. The default value is "true".

context.name: Containers
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the memory allocation rules for each container.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to display container memory allocation settings and runtime values.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify the memory allocation settings for a container. For the purpose of the set command, the memory can be expressed as an amount of memory (in megs) or a percentage of physical memory. Modifying one of the values causes the other to be recalculated.

parameter.name: containerName
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the container name.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to modify.

parameter.name: amount
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the amount of memory that is allocated to a container (in megs).

parameter.name: percentage
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the percentage of physical memory that is allocated to a container.

context.name: Security
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Access Control List (ACL) security options for the server.

context.name: BlackList
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Access Control List (ACL) black list security options for the BroadWorks server.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to display network security-related attributes. It displays the Access Control List (ACL) black list that filters inbound network packets to the BroadWorks server. Packets that match entries in the black list are processed by the BroadWorks server.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add an entry to the Access Control List (ACL) black list.

parameter.name: SourceAddress
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the sourceIp/sourceMask pair as a subnet range of IPs. The sourceIp is always the string representation of the IP whether IPv4 or IPv6.

parameter.name: Mask
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the source mask. It is in dotted string format for IPv4 (for example, 255.255.0.0) or the number of bits in the mask for IPv4 and IPv6.

parameter.name: DestinationAddress
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the destination IP address of the packet matches against this IP address. This is one of the configured IP addresses of the BroadWorks server.

parameter.name: destinationPortFirst
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the first port of the range of inbound packets that match against a range of destination ports. For protocol Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP), this is "0".

parameter.name: destinationPortLast
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the last port of the range of inbound packets that match against a range of destination ports. For protocol Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP), this is "0".

parameter.name: protocol
parameter.description: This parameter determines the received network packet matches against this protocol. Values include" "tcp", "udp", or "icmp".

command.name: delete
command.description: This command is used to remove an entry from the Access Control List (ACL) black list.

parameter.name: SourceAddress
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the sourceIp/sourceMask pair as a subnet range of IPs. The sourceIp/sourceMask pair defines a subnet range of IPs. The sourceIp is always the string representation of the IP whether IPv4 or IPv6.

parameter.name: Mask
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the sourceMask is in dotted string for IPv4 (for example, 255.255.0.0) or the number of bits in the mask for IPv4 and IPv6.

parameter.name: DestinationAddress
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the destination IP address of the packet matches against this IP address. This is one of the configured IP addresses of the BroadWorks server.

parameter.name: destinationPortFirst
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the first port of the range of inbound packets that match against a range of destination ports. For protocol Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP), this is "0".

parameter.name: destinationPortLast
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the last port of the range of inbound packets that match against a range of destination ports. For protocol Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP), this is "0".

parameter.name: protocol
parameter.description: This parameter determines the received network packet matches against this protocol. Values include: "tcp", "udp", or "icmp".

context.name: WhiteList
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Access Control List (ACL) white list security options for the BroadWorks server.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to display the network security-related attributes. It displays the Access Control List white list that filters inbound network packets to the BroadWorks Server. Packets match entries in the white list to be processed by the BroadWorks server.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add an entry to the Access Control List ( ACL) white list.

parameter.name: SourceAddress
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the sourceIp/sourceMask pair as a subnet range of IPs. The sourceIp is always the string representation of the IP whether IPv4 or IPv6.

parameter.name: Mask
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the sourceMask is in dotted string for IPv4 (for example, 255.255.0.0) or the number of bits in the mask for IPv4 and IPv6.

parameter.name: DestinationAddress
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the destination IP address of the packet matches against this IP address. This is one of the configured IP addresses of the BroadWorks Server.

parameter.name: destinationPortFirst
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the first port of the range of inbound packets that match against a range of destination ports. For protocol Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP), this is "0".

parameter.name: destinationPortLast
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the last port of the range of inbound packets that match against a range of destination ports. For protocol Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP), this is "0".

parameter.name: protocol
parameter.description: This parameter determines the received network packet matches against this protocol. Values include: "tcp", "udp", or "icmp".

command.name: delete
command.description: This command is used to remove an entry from the Access Control List (ACL) white list.

parameter.name: SourceAddress
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the sourceIp/sourceMask pair as a subnet range of IPs. The sourceIp/sourceMask pair defines a subnet range of IPs. The sourceIp is always the string representation of the IP whether IPv4 or IPv6.

parameter.name: Mask
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the sourceMask is in dotted string for IPv4 (for example, 255.255.0.0) or the number of bits in the mask for IPv4 and IPv6.

parameter.name: DestinationAddress
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the destination IP address of the packet matches against this IP address. This is one of the configured IP addresses of the BroadWorks Server.

parameter.name: destinationPortFirst
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the first port of the range of inbound packets that match against a range of destination ports. For protocol Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP), this is "0".

parameter.name: destinationPortLast
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the last port of the range of inbound packets that match against a range of destination ports. For protocol Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP), this is "0".

parameter.name: protocol
parameter.description: This parameter determines the received network packet matches against this protocol. Values include: "tcp", "udp", or "icmp".

context.name: StartupParam
context.description: This level is used to view and modify Network Server properties.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the system parameter-related attributes.

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: The name of a system startup parameter.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify the system parameter-related attributes.

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: The name of a system startup parameter.

parameter.name: publicIPAddress
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the public Internet Protocol (IP) address of the Network Server. This is the interface address for all access-side traffic (toward access devices).

parameter.name: publicIPv6Address
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the public IPv6 address of the Network Server. This is the interface IPv6 address to use for all access-side traffic (toward access devices).

command.name: clear
command.description: This command is used to clear the (set to no value) system parameter-related attributes.

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: The name of a system startup parameter.

context.name: SubscriberHosting
context.description: This level is used to manage subscriber-hosting related attributes.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view subscriber-hosting attributes.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify subscriber-hosting attributes.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to modify.

parameter.name: proxyRouteAdvanceTimeoutMillis
parameter.description: Specifies the timeout in milliseconds that the Network Server waits for a response when proxying SIP calls to the user's hosting NE node. If no response is received within this timeout period, the Network Server does route advance to the next node in its list in order to find a hosting NE node for the user. The default value is 2000.

parameter.name: proxySessionTimeoutInSeconds
parameter.description: Specifies the timeout value in seconds before the Network Server terminate an idle proxying session.

parameter.name: dataCenterId
parameter.description: The data center id of the current Network Server peer. Each Network Server peer can have its own value (i.e. the data center id is per-host, not per-cluster). There is no default value.

parameter.name: maxNumRoutesInMatchingDataCenter
parameter.description: When the Network Server orders possible routes by putting first the routes with a data center id matching the data center id of the current Network Server node, this parameter specifies the maximum number of matching data center routes that are put in the route list before other routes in other data center ids are added to the list.

parameter.name: numFailuresAboveSuccessesBeforeMigration
parameter.description: Specifies the number of failures above successes before migration is triggered. 0 means never migrate. The Network Server does not migrate an enterprise upon N failures, but rather when the rate of failures exceeds the rate of successes such that the number of failures exceeds the number of successes by N (N being the value assigned to numFailuresAboveSuccessesBeforeMigration).

command.name: doAudit
command.description: This command forces a re-distribution of subscribers among the available Hosting NEs in a set. In each Hosting NE, it also re-distributes the subscribers among the nodes in the cluster, a node being an Execution Server (XS). The re-distribution algorithm optimizes the usage of clusters and nodes in the network. The re-distribution may force the migration of subscribers from one node to another and the changes take effect immediately. This may result in the mass-migration of subscribers in the network, forcing Execution Servers to start hosting new subscribers, increasing real-time, memory, and network usage in nodes of the network. Therefore, this command should only be used during a low traffic maintenance window.

context.name: Util
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Network Server utilities. The Network Server has the following utility levels: *ASUpload: Used to upload Application Server data to the Network Server. *Diag: Used to use diagnostic tools for troubleshooting Network Server devices. *Policy: Used to view deployable policies and to upload new policies. *Verif: Used to verify translations and Media Server selection results.

context.name: ASUpload
context.description: This level is used to move information from the Application Server to the Network Server.

command.name: status
command.description: This command is used to view the status of the Application Server Upload command.

command.name: upload
command.description: This command is used to upload Application Server data to the Network Server. The Application Server data is contained in an XML file. A log file is produced.

parameter.name: asNE
parameter.description: The name of the hosting NE.

parameter.name: uploadFileName
parameter.description: The location and name of the dump file to upload.

parameter.name: logFileName
parameter.description: The location and name of the file in which to log the operation.

context.name: Diag
context.description: This level is used to diagnose problems with connected devices.

command.name: Heap
command.description: This command is used to view the heap usage of the application.

parameter.name: mainOption
parameter.description: Specifies how much information is shown.

command.name: PingDevice
command.description: This command is used to verify the online status of a device connected to the Network Server.

parameter.name: choice
parameter.description: Specify the type of device to ping.

parameter.name: HostingNE
parameter.description: The name of the hosting Network Element (NE) to ping.

parameter.name: RoutingNE
parameter.description: The name of the routing Network Element (NE) to ping.

parameter.name: ResourceNE
parameter.description: The name of the resource Network Element (NE) to ping.

parameter.name: deviceAddress
parameter.description: The device address and its options.

parameter.name: ipAddress
parameter.description: The IP address, host name, or domain of the device to ping.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Additional ping attribute(s).

parameter.name: port
parameter.description: Specifies the port for this device.

parameter.name: transportType
parameter.description: Specifies which transport type is used by this device. When unspecified is selected, either protocol is allowed.

context.name: Policy
context.description: This level is used to view and upload all available policies.

command.name: get
command.description: The policies that can be deployed by the Network Server can be viewed using this command.

command.name: load
command.description: New deployable policies can be loaded on the Network Server using this command.

parameter.name: all
parameter.description: Load all available policies.

context.name: Verif
context.description: This level is used to verify translation results.

command.name: vtr
command.description: This command is used to verify translation results. This command allows you to debug any problems between the originator phone number (the caller) and the terminator phone number (the called party) as it emulates the Network Server as it connects these two phone numbers. A detailed report displays showing information, warnings, and errors.

parameter.name: Originator DN
parameter.description: The DN of the originating caller. If the originator DN is not specified as DN@host, then it must be specified using the E.164 DN format.

parameter.name: Terminator DN
parameter.description: The DN being called.

parameter.name: option
parameter.description: Used to specify additional vtr option(s).

parameter.name: phoneContext
parameter.description: Use to simulate an incoming SIP INVITE message with a phone-context attached to it.

parameter.name: viaHost
parameter.description: Used to simulate an incoming SIP INVITE message with a viaHost different from the host in the FROM field.

parameter.name: mssGWAddr
parameter.description: Simulates the address, host, or domain of a routing NE for which closest Media Servers are required.

parameter.name: sourceId
parameter.description: Used to simulate an incoming SIP OTG parameter, so the vtr command can show how this parameter is used at call processing time to identify the call originator, which can be an enterprise, site, or user group.

parameter.name: accessNetworkInfo
parameter.description: The name of the P-Access-Network-Info header.

parameter.name: mediaCodec
parameter.description: Specifies an optional codec entry list for call tracing using the verify translation and routing (vtr) utility.

parameter.name: event
parameter.description: The name of the Event header.

parameter.name: nti
parameter.description: A Network Translation Indicator.

parameter.name: rn
parameter.description: Specifies an optional Routing Number telephone-subscriber parameter within the Request URI. If the rn is populated, the npdi telephone-subscriber parameter is also included within the RequestURI.

parameter.name: rnContext
parameter.description: Specifies an optional Routing Number Context telephone-subscriber parameter within the Request URI.

parameter.name: scfTrigger
parameter.description: SCF Server Trigger for Mobile Origination or Mobile Termination.

command.name: vtri
command.description: This command is used to perform verification of translation results with a Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) message as input. The SIP message can be entered by directly typing it at the console (input mode) or via a file (file mode).In the input mode, the user can enter as many characters as required, including carriage returns. The input mode is terminated by entering a single period (.) on a line.

parameter.name: File
parameter.description: Specifies the name of the file that contains the SIP message used for translation.

context.name: NSDiagnostic
context.description: This level is used to access the Network Server diagnostic commands.

context.name: OverloadControls

command.name: detail

parameter.name: ipAddress

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to set the current overload zone value for non-call processing.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to modify.

parameter.name: currentZone
parameter.description: The non-call processing overload zone.

command.name: clear

parameter.name: attribute

context.name: QueueStats
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the internal queues statistics.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to get the internal queues statistics.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to configure the internal queue statistics.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to modify.

parameter.name: sampleIntervalSeconds
parameter.description: The sample interval in seconds.

parameter.name: counts
parameter.description: This attribute can take one of the following values: *reset:Resets the queue statistics data to zero. *sampleOff: Turns off sampling (if samplingInterval is set).

context.name: SubscriberMgmt
context.description: This level is used to display, add, modify, and delete the attributes related to administrators, enterprises, and users.

context.name: Administrator

context.name: HostingNEUser

command.name: get

parameter.name: attribute

parameter.name: userId
parameter.description: The user ID for the administrator. Acceptable characters are letters, digits, and the following special characters: ! # $ % & + - / = ? ^ _ ` { | }. ~ @ ' *.

parameter.name: subscriberMaintenancePartition
parameter.description: The Subscriber Maintenance Partition to consider.

parameter.name: userId
parameter.description: The user ID for the administrator. Acceptable characters are letters, digits, and the following special characters: ! # $ % & + - / = ? ^ _ ` { | }. ~ @ ' *.

parameter.name: hostNE
parameter.description: The hosting NE to which the administrator belongs.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Additional attributes to include through the set command.

parameter.name: subscriberMaintenancePartition
parameter.description: The Subscriber Maintenance Partition this administrator should be part of.

parameter.name: userId
parameter.description: The administrator's user ID.

parameter.name: hostNE
parameter.description: The hosting NE to which the administrator is added.

parameter.name: userId
parameter.description: The user ID for the administrator. Acceptable characters are letters, digits, and the following special characters: ! # $ % & + - / = ? ^ _ ` { | }. ~ @ ' *.

parameter.name: hostNE

parameter.name: attribute

context.name: User
context.description: This level is used to display, add, modify, and delete administrative users.

parameter.name: userId

parameter.name: firstName
