context.name: NetworkVoicePortal
context.description: This level is used to display, add, and delete the network Voice Portal Directory Number (DN).

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the Network Voice Portal Directory Numbers (DNs) pool and their associated system voice portal information.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add Directory Numbers (DNs) to the Network Voice Portal DNs pool. More than one DN can be specified. DNs can be entered as individual numbers or as a range of numbers. When adding a DN to a record, the new DN is appended to the current list of DNs for that record.

parameter.name: number
parameter.description: List of DNs to be added to the system (Separated by a space or a comma for individual DNs or by a hyphen for a range of DNs).

command.name: delete
command.description: This command is used to delete the Directory Numbers (DNs) from the Network Voice Portal DNs pool. DNs can be entered as individual DNs or as a range of DNs.

parameter.name: number
parameter.description: List of DN to be deleted from the system (Separated by a space or a comma for individual DNs or by a hyphen for a range of DNs).

context.name: Numbers
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the phone numbers for system providers and enterprises.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the phone numbers for system providers and enterprises. The number management state refers to the management of unassigned numbers. When number management is disabled, all unassigned numbers are deleted, and no new unassigned numbers can be added. Numbers assigned to groups are not affected.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to change unable or disable number management. Disabling number management only affects the management of unassigned numbers. When number management is disabled, all unassigned numbers are deleted, and no unassigned numbers can be added. Numbers assigned to groups are not affected.

parameter.name: enableNumberMgmt
parameter.description: Controls if number management for unassigned numbers is disabled or enabled.

context.name: UnassignedNumbers
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the unassigned numbers settings. The unassigned numbers feature provides enhanced management for the phone or directory numbers (DNs) owned by the system provider. The Network Server manages pools of assigned and unassigned DNs such that calls are properly routed to a destination-hosting device or a system treatment. This feature is characterized by the fact that DNs assigned to user groups are automatically removed from the pool of unassigned DNs. DNs deleted from user groups are automatically put back into the pool of unassigned DNs. DNs added or removed through the Sync Application Programming Interface (API) or the Operations Support System (OSS) interfaces are subject to the same rules as the CLI. New DNs can be added to user groups without having to be in the unassigned DN pool first. DNs assigned to groups on a BroadWorks Application Server but not assigned to end users, are still considered assigned on the Network Server.

command.name: get
command.description: Unassigned DNs are viewed using this command.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add a new unassigned number. Numbers can be entered as individual numbers (for example, 13335551234, 13335559090) and/or as ranges (for example, 13335551234-13335551240, and 13335559090).

parameter.name: dn
parameter.description: The unassigned DNs to be added. (Separated by a space or a comma for individual DNs, or by a hyphen for a range of DNs).

command.name: delete
command.description: Unassigned DNs can be deleted. DNs can be entered as individual DNs or as a range of DNs. The unique DN is used to delete the associated record.

parameter.name: dn
parameter.description: his command is used to add a new unassigned number (separated by a space or a comma for individual DNs or by a hyphen for a range of DNs).

context.name: PasswordRules
context.description: This level is used to view and modify password attributes for enterprise administrators.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view enterprise password-related attributes including the allowable login failures, minimum password length, expiration, and whether the password can be the same as the user ID or must contain numbers.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify enterprise password-related attributes including the allowable login failures, minimum password length, expiration, and whether the password can be the same as the user ID or must contain numbers.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to modify.

parameter.name: containNonAlphaNumChars
parameter.description: The number of non-alphanumeric characters that must be present in the password.

parameter.name: containNonAlphaNum
parameter.description: Controls if rhe password have to contain or not non-alphanumeric characters.

parameter.name: containLowerAlphaChars
parameter.description: The number of lower case alphabetic characters the password must contain.

parameter.name: containLowerAlpha
parameter.description: Controls if the password does have to contain or not lower-case alphabetic characters.

parameter.name: containUpperAlphaChars
parameter.description: The number of upper-case alphabetic characters the password must contain.

parameter.name: containUpperAlpha
parameter.description: Controls if the password does have to contain or not upper-case alphabetic characters.

parameter.name: containNumberChars
parameter.description: The number of numeric characters the password must contain.

parameter.name: containNumber
parameter.description: Controls if the password does have to contain or not numeric characters.

parameter.name: notReverseOfOldPassword
parameter.description: When set to false, the password is allowed to be the reverse characters of the previous password. When set to true, the password cannot be the reverse characters of the previous password.

parameter.name: notContainOldPassword
parameter.description: Controls if the password is allowed to be part of the previous password or not.

parameter.name: notUserId
parameter.description: Controls if the password can be the same as the user ID or not.

parameter.name: minimumLength
parameter.description: The minimum length allowed for passwords.

parameter.name: expirationDays
parameter.description: The number of days after which the password expires and the user is forced to change the password.

parameter.name: allowableLoginFailures
parameter.description: The number of login failures allowed. After the specified number of failures, the user is blocked and must contact an administrator for password change.

context.name: ResourceDN
context.description: This level is used to display, add, and delete the Resource Directory Numbers (ResourceDN) settings.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the Directory Numbers (DNs) in a resource DN pool. Using the command alone displays all records. Using the command with a specific variable displays records matching those criteria. The numbers are displayed as either a list of individual DNs or a range of DNs.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to filter on.

parameter.name: hostNE
parameter.description: The Network Element (NE) hosting the group.

parameter.name: number
parameter.description: List of DNs to search in the system (Separated by a space or a comma for individual DNs or by a hyphen for a range of DNs).

parameter.name: poolType
parameter.description: The type of DN pool.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add Directory Numbers (DNs) to a resource DN pool. More than one DN can be specified. DNs can be entered as individual numbers or as a range of DNs. When adding a DN to a record, the new DN is appended to the current list of DNs for that record.

parameter.name: hostNE
parameter.description: The Network Element (NE) hosting the DN.

parameter.name: number
parameter.description: List of DNs to be added to the system (Separated by a space or a comma for individual DNs or by a hyphen for a range of DNs).

parameter.name: poolType
parameter.description: The type of DN pool.

parameter.name: IMRN
parameter.description: IP Multimedia Routing Number (IMRN) pool type.

parameter.name: hostNENodeID
parameter.description: The node id of the Hosting NE.

parameter.name: SCC
parameter.description: Service Centralization Continuity (SCC) pool type.

parameter.name: hostNENodeID
parameter.description: The node id of the Hosting NE.

command.name: delete
command.description: This command is used to delete Directory Numbers (DNs) from a resource DN pool. More than one DN can be specified. DNs can be entered as individual DNs or as a range of DNs. When deleting a DN from a record, only the specified DN is removed from the current list of DNs for that record.

parameter.name: hostNE
parameter.description: The Network Element (NE) hosting the DN.

parameter.name: number
parameter.description: List of DN to be deleted from the system (Separated by a space or a comma for individual DNs or by a hyphen for a range of DNs).

context.name: SubscriberMaintenancePartition
context.description: This level is used to view and modify subscriber maintenance partition settings. A subscriber maintenance partition provides a way to group together service provider groups and/or service providers/enterprises that should logically be upgraded/roll backed together (or more generally, maintained together). It is a grouping of subscribers that share the same upgrade/rollback characteristics. A service provider group or a service provider/enterprise can only be part of one Subscriber Maintenance Partition at a time. Use this level to get Subscriber Maintenance Partitions.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the subscriber maintenance partitions.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to filter on.

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: The name of an existing Subscriber Maintenance Partition.

context.name: NEMaintenancePartition
context.description: This level is used to add, get, and delete Network Element (NE) maintenance partition associations to subscriber maintenance partitions.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the subscriber maintenance partition to Network Element (NE) maintenance partition associations.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to filter on.

parameter.name: subscriberMaintenancePartitionName
parameter.description: The name of a Subscriber Maintenance Partition.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to assign a subscriber maintenance partition to Network Element (NE) maintenance partition associations. A Subscriber Maintenance Partition can only be assigned one NE maintenance partition.

parameter.name: subscriberMaintenancePartitionName
parameter.description: The name of the Subscriber Maintenance Partition.

parameter.name: NEMaintenancePartitionName
parameter.description: The name of the NE Maintenance Partition.

command.name: delete
command.description: his command is used to delete a subscriber maintenance partition from Network Element (NE) maintenance partition associations.

parameter.name: subscriberMaintenancePartitionName
parameter.description: The name of the Subscriber Maintenance Partition.

parameter.name: NEMaintenancePartitionName
parameter.description: The name of the NE Maintenance Partition.

context.name: SystemServices
context.description: This level is used to display, add, and delete the attributes related to system services (SystemServices).

context.name: Dn
context.description: This level is used to display, add, and delete the attributes related to system services DNs.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the Directory Numbers (DNs) for system services. Using the command alone displays all records. Using the command with a specific variable displays records matching those criteria.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to filter on.

parameter.name: hostNE
parameter.description: The Network Element (NE) hosting the DN.

parameter.name: number
parameter.description: List of DNs to search in the system (Separated by a space or a comma for individual DNs or by a hyphen for a range of DNs).

parameter.name: systemSvc
parameter.description: The type of system service. When a DN is first added the service type will be SYS_SVC_DN. When associated with a different system service the type will match the acronym for the service.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add Directory Numbers (DNs) for system services. More than one DN can be specified. DNs can be entered as individual numbers or as a range of DNs. When adding a DN to a record, the new DN is appended to the current list of DNs for that record.

parameter.name: hostNE
parameter.description: The Network Element (NE) hosting the DN.

parameter.name: number
parameter.description: List of DNs to be added to the system (Separated by a space or a comma for individual DNs or by a hyphen for a range of DNs).

command.name: delete
command.description: This command is used to delete Directory Numbers (DNs) associated with system services. More than one DN can be specified. DNs can be entered as individual DNs or as a range of DNs. DNs associated with a specific service may not be deleted till they are unassigned and back to the Sys_SVC_DN pool.

parameter.name: hostNE
parameter.description: The Network Element (NE) hosting the DN.

parameter.name: number
parameter.description: List of DN to be deleted from the system (Separated by a space or a comma for individual DNs or by a hyphen for a range of DNs).

context.name: Service
context.description: This level is used to display, add, and delete the attributes related to system services entries.

command.name: get
command.description: The system services entries. Using the command alone displays all records. Using the command with a specific variable displays records matching those criteria.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add system services entries.

parameter.name: hostNE
parameter.description: The Network Element (NE) hosting the system service entry.

parameter.name: url
parameter.description: The URL associated with the individual system service entry.

parameter.name: systemSvc
parameter.description: The type of system service to add.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The optional attribute name.

parameter.name: systemDN
parameter.description: The associated system service DN.

parameter.name: networkDN
parameter.description: The associated network DN.

parameter.name: uri
parameter.description: The associated public identity.

command.name: set

parameter.name: hostNE
parameter.description: The Network Element (NE) hosting the entry.

parameter.name: url
parameter.description: The URL of system service entry to update.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to filter on.

parameter.name: systemDN
parameter.description: The desired value for the associated system service DN.

parameter.name: networkDN
parameter.description: The desired value for the associated network DN.

parameter.name: uri
parameter.description: The desired value for the associated public identity.

parameter.name: newURL
parameter.description: the desired value for the URL.

command.name: delete
command.description: This command is used to delete a system service entry. The associated systemDn returns to the SYS_SVC_DN pool.

parameter.name: hostNE
parameter.description: The Network Element (NE) hosting the system service entry.

parameter.name: url
parameter.description: The URL associated with the individual system service entry.

context.name: Policy
context.description: This level is used to view and modify routing policies and profiles. Routing policies can be defined as having instances that are a variation of the policy. Instances are assigned to routing profiles, and profiles are then associated with enterprises and user groups to instruct the Network Server on the routing rules for that enterprise or user group.

context.name: CallScreening
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Call Screening policy. The Call Screening (CallScreening) routing policy provides call screening on a per-country code basis. The Call Screening routing policy works with the North American Numbering Plan. It allows validating that the Call Type found by the Call Typing policy is coherent with NPA/NXXs implied in the call. Knowing the NPA/NXX of the originator and at least the NXX of the terminator, Call Screening searches the NPA/NXX Active Code List (NNACL) and Local Calling Area File (LCA) database to determine the category of the call (Local, Intra-LATA toll, Inter-LATA). It therefore validates the Call Type found by Call Typing. This policy uses the standard NNACL file, provided by Telcordia for North America, to search the rate center (RC) and the Local Area Transport Area (LATA) related to a NPA/NXX. The LCA is a client specific file that specifies a list of originating rate centers and their related terminating rate center/NPANXX for which the call shall be categorized as local (non Intra-LATA toll).

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the Call Screening policy attributes.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add a Call Screening policy instance.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

parameter.name: Enable
parameter.description: Controls if this policies is enabled or not. When a policy is disabled, it is ignored by the NS during call processing even if assigned.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Additional attributes to include through the add command.

parameter.name: CallTypes
parameter.description: The type of call this policy instance can process.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify Call Screening policy attributes.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Attribute to modify.

parameter.name: Enable
parameter.description: Controls if this policies is enabled or not. When a policy is disabled, it is ignored by the NS during call processing even if assigned.

parameter.name: CallTypes
parameter.description: The type of call this policy instance can process.

command.name: delete
command.description: This command is used to delete a Call Screening policy instance.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

context.name: CallTypeProcessingRules
context.description: This level is used to view, add, delete, and modify attributes for the Call Type Processing Rules.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the existing Call Type processing rules.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Attribute to filter on.

parameter.name: incomingCallType
parameter.description: This indicates the call type (that was determined by Call Typing), for which the rule applies. Note that this column can have a value of ALL, but specific matches have precedence.

parameter.name: translatedCategory
parameter.description: This indicates the category determined by Call Screening, for which the rule applies. Note that this column can only take the values LOCAL, NATIONAL, INTERLATA and INTRALATA.

parameter.name: E164Call
parameter.description: This indicates if the rule applies to E.164 calls or non-E.164 calls.

parameter.name: unconditional
parameter.description: This indicates if the rule applies to all calls or only to calls where the incomingCallType default category does not match the translatedCategory (that is, only when the category is being overridden).

parameter.name: action
parameter.description: This is the action the CallScreening policy should take when a rule matches all conditions. The supported actions are: CT=xxx, TRMT=xxx, CI={Y|N} and PRFX. The CT action changes to call type to the one specified. The TRMT action rejects the call with the specified treatment. The PRFX action adds the national prefix to the digits. Multiple actions can be defined for each rule (for example, CT=xxx, PRFX).

parameter.name: revXlaApplicable
parameter.description: This flag controls whether or not the rule applies in the case of a reverse translation query.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add a Call Type processing rules entry.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: This is the name of the policy instance.

parameter.name: incomingCallType
parameter.description: This indicates the call type (that was determined by Call Typing), for which the rule applies. Note that this column can have a value of ALL, but specific matches have precedence.

parameter.name: translatedCategory
parameter.description: This indicates the category determined by Call Screening, for which the rule applies. Note that this column can only take the values LOCAL, NATIONAL, INTERLATA and INTRALATA.

parameter.name: E164Call
parameter.description: This indicates if the rule applies to E.164 calls or non-E.164 calls.

parameter.name: unconditional
parameter.description: This indicates if the rule applies to all calls or only to calls where the incomingCallType default category does not match the translatedCategory (that is, only when the category is being overridden).

parameter.name: action
parameter.description: This is the action the Call Screening policy should take when a rule matches all conditions. The supported actions are CT=xxx, TRMT=xxx, CI={Y|N} and PRFX. The CT action changes to call type to the one specified. The TRMT action rejects the call with the specified treatment. The PRFX action adds the national prefix to the digits.Multiple actions can be defined for each rule (for example, CT=xxx, PRFX).

parameter.name: revXlaApplicable
parameter.description: This flag controls whether or not the rule applies in the case of a reverse translation query.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify the Call Type processing rules entry-related attributes.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: This is the name of the policy instance.

parameter.name: incomingCallType
parameter.description: This indicates the call type (that was determined by Call Typing), for which the rule applies. Note that this column can have a value of ALL, but specific matches have precedence.

parameter.name: translatedCategory
parameter.description: This indicates the category determined by Call Screening, for which the rule applies. Note that this column can only take the values LOCAL, NATIONAL, INTERLATA and INTRALATA.

parameter.name: E164Call
parameter.description: This indicates if the rule applies to E.164 calls or non-E.164 calls.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Attribute to modify.

parameter.name: unconditional
parameter.description: This indicates if the rule applies to all calls or only to calls where the incomingCallType default category does not match the translatedCategory (that is, only when the category is being overridden).

parameter.name: action
parameter.description: This is the action the CallScreening policy should take when a rule matches all conditions. The supported actions are CT=xxx, TRMT=xxx, CI={Y|N} and PRFX. The CT action changes to call type to the one specified. The TRMT action rejects the call with the specified treatment. The PRFX action adds the national prefix to the digits. Multiple actions can be defined for each rule (for example, CT=xxx, PRFX).

parameter.name: revXlaApplicable
parameter.description: This flag controls whether or not the rule applies in the case of a reverse translation query.

command.name: delete
command.description: This command is used to delete an existing Call Type processing rules entry.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: This is the name of the policy instance.

parameter.name: incomingCallType
parameter.description: This indicates the call type (that was determined by Call Typing), for which the rule applies. Note that this column may have a value of ALL, but specific matches have precedence.

parameter.name: translatedCategory
parameter.description: This indicates the category determined by Call Screening, for which the rule applies. Note that this column can only take the values LOCAL, NATIONAL, INTERLATA and INTRALATA.

parameter.name: E164Call
parameter.description: This indicates if the rule applies to E.164 calls or non-E.164 calls.

context.name: CallTyping
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the call typing settings. The Network Server's routing logic is based on call-typing determination. The Network Server analyzes the called party number to determine the type of call that the caller wants to make. This call type result is then used by routing policies to determine the processing to be applied to the call. The Call Typing (CallTyping) policy instance uses the dial plan associated to the country code of the call originator. The Call Typing routing policy performs pre-screening of incoming calls using an operator defined dial plan. A dial plan defines the meaning of various dialed digit sequences, and thus allows recognition of long distance calls, operator assisted calls, emergency calls, and other specific types of calls. Call types identified through this policy allow subsequent policies to apply or not for a given call. The Network Server is delivered with default public dial plans. The Network Server provides support for the public North American Dial Plan, thus provides support for all North American call types.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the Call Typing policy instance attributes.

context.name: EASvcCallRtg
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Equal Access Service Call Routing (EASvcCallRtg) policy that a system provider to map Equal Access (EA) service calls to specific carriers. It is used by a system provider to force specific service calls to be routed to specific carriers using the carrier's Carrier Identification Code (CIC). This implies that if a call is made to a configured service NPA or NPANXX the Network Server includes the configured CIC in the returned contact list. In North America, Personal Service Calls (500NXX calls) and Premium Service Calls (900NXX calls), are calls that must be routed to specific carriers. Similar rules apply to other call types, such as 800, 811, and 888 calls. The EASvcCallRtg policy allows a system provider to route calls by selecting a CIC based on the dialed digits rather than the calling party.

parameter.name: CallTypes

context.name: EqualAccess
context.description: This level is used to modify and view the Equal Access (EqualAccess) routing policy. This policy applies to toll calls (intra-LATA or inter-LATA toll), and to international calls, with or without CAC (101+XXXX) dialed. This policy is triggered either through Casual Access Calls or using a caller Preferred Exchange Carrier. It implies that toll calls, intra-LATA, inter-LATA or international, are carried by a carrier that may differ from the serving operating company (generally the owner of the Network Server). This policy allows an operator to associate or not associate a carrier with a list of POPs. When a list of POPs is provided for a carrier, the call is routed to the POP closest to the originator (from that list only). In this scenario, the CIC is stored as the TSP tag in the returned SIP response. When a list of POPs is not provided, the outgoing call is routed to the POP closest to the call originator (selected among all POPs configured on the Network Server).When several POPs have the same routing cost, the Network Server reorders the list of results based on a weighted randomization.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the Equal Access policy attributes.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add an Equal Access instance.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

parameter.name: Enable
parameter.description: Controls if this policies is enabled or not. When a policy is disabled, it is ignored by the NS during call processing even if assigned.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Additional attributes to include through the add command.

parameter.name: CallTypes
parameter.description: The type of call this policy instance can process.

parameter.name: BlockUnknownCac
parameter.description: When set to false, if the Network Server receives a CAC dialed by a user, and if this CAC is not defined in the system, equal access continues by processing the call through the Near End Routing policy. When set to true, if the Network Server receives a CAC dialed by a user, and if this CAC is not defined in the system, the call is not completed and goes to treatment.

parameter.name: CicAlways
parameter.description: When set to false, the policy instance is not required to include a CIC in the returned contacts. When set to true, the policy instance must always include a CIC parameter in the returned contacts.

parameter.name: addCICasCAC
parameter.description: When set to never, no special action is taken by the Network Server regarding the CIC. This is the default value. When set to nsOnly, the Network Server returns the CIC as if it were dialed by the caller. It prepends the called party number with the caller's default carrier prefix followed by the CIC, simply interpreted as a CAC (Carrier Access Code). When set to alwaysIfSub, the Network Server adds the CIC as a CAC if the carrier selection is made by the Network Server or by the Application Server with a subscribed PIC. When set to either nsOnly or alwaysIfSub, it has no impact on URL calls or when the called party number received by the Network Server is a global E.164 number.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify the attributes of the Equal Access policy.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Attribute to modify.

parameter.name: Enable
parameter.description: Controls if this policies is enabled or not. When a policy is disabled, it is ignored by the NS during call processing even if assigned.

parameter.name: CallTypes
parameter.description: The type of call this policy instance can process.

parameter.name: BlockUnknownCac
parameter.description: When set tp false, if the Network Server receives a CAC dialed by a user, and if this CAC is not defined in the system, equal access continues by processing the call through the Near End Routing policy. When set to true, if the Network Server receives a CAC dialed by a user, and if this CAC is not defined in the system, the call is not completed and goes to treatment.

parameter.name: CicAlways
parameter.description: When set tp false, the policy instance is not required to include a CIC parameter in the returned contacts. When set to true, the policy instance must always include a CIC parameter in the returned contacts.

parameter.name: addCICasCAC
parameter.description: When set to never, no special action is taken by the Network Server regarding the CIC. When set to nsOnly, the Network Server returns the CIC as if it were dialed by the caller. It prepends the called party number with the caller's default carrier prefix followed by the CIC, simply interpreted as a CAC (Carrier Access Code). When set to alwaysIfSub, the Network Server adds the CIC as a CAC if the carrier selection is made by the Network Server or by the Application Server with a subscribed PIC. When set to either nsOnly or alwaysIfSub, it has no impact on URL calls or when the called party number received by the Network Server is a global E.164 number.

context.name: FarEndRtg
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Far-End Routing (FarEndRtg) policy. This policy provides network level routing for off-network routing. It is used to select the routing path using rules that ensure the least-cost. It identifies the POP closest to the call destination, for example, between an IP network and the PSTN. This policy can be used in conjunction with the Tandem Overflow policy, in which case, the Overflow attribute should be set to "true" and the Location Routing attribute should be set to "false" to disable the V&H lookup.

command.name: get

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Additional attributes to include through the add command.

parameter.name: CallTypes
parameter.description: The type of call this policy instance can process.

parameter.name: LocationRouting
parameter.description: Only Routing entries are used and Location-based search is not used, this is the default. Also used to disable V&H lookup for the Tandem Overflow policy.

parameter.name: Overflow
parameter.description: This policy instance ignores Tandem Overflow, this is the default.

parameter.name: instance

parameter.description: Only Routing entries are used and Location-based search is not used, this is the default. Also used to disable V&H lookup for Tandem Overflow policy.

context.name: MediaSrvSel
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Media Server Selection (MediaSrvSel) policy. This policy decouples BroadWorks Media Servers from Application Servers. Instead of imposing collocation of these servers, this Network Server routing policy allows the operating company to physically locate the Media Servers close to access and/or network gateways. It allows Media Servers to:Be shared among Application ServersMinimize latency due to the number of hops between a Media Server and an end-user point of presence (POP)Release bandwidth usage from a service provider network.

parameter.name: to
parameter.description: The decimal digit '0-9' sequence defining the end of a range of digits.

parameter.name: routingNe
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the routing Network Element (NE).

parameter.name: cost
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the associated cost code for the routing number digit pattern and Network Element (NE) mapping with the value 1 is the lowest and the value 9 is the highest.

parameter.name: weight
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the weight of the routing number digit pattern and Network Element (NE) mapping. Given the same cost, routing number digit pattern and Network Element (NE) mappings are randomly listed according to weight with a higher weight appearing more often at the top. The value 0 is the lowest and the value 99 is the highest.

context.name: OrigRedirect
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Originator Redirect (OrigRedirect) routing policy. This policy allows for the BroadWorks hosting of PSTN users. This policy is originator-based, meaning that it performs its routing logic based on the calling DN (this policy does not apply to URL calls). If triggered, the policy tries to redirect the incoming call to the hosting NE of the caller so that this NE can carry out the task of originating the call for the caller. If the policy cannot complete the processing (for example, the caller is not known in the system or the hosting NE has no address in the system), OrigRedirect passes processing to the next policy. If a result is found, no other policy can process this call and contacts are returned.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the attributes related to the Originator Redirect policy.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add an Originator Redirect instance to the system.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

parameter.name: Enable
parameter.description: Controls if this policies is enabled or not. When a policy is disabled, it is ignored by the NS during call processing even if assigned.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Additional attributes to include through the add command.

parameter.name: CallTypes
parameter.description: The type of call this policy instance can process.

parameter.name: applyAccessSideRules
parameter.description: When set to "true", the call is redirected to either a line/port or a trunk group, depending on the value of supportTrunkGroupLookups. When set to "false", the call is redirected to a directory number (DN) and the value of supportTrunkGroupLookups is ignored.

parameter.name: supportTrunkGroupLookups
parameter.description: When set to "disable", the policy instance ignores any tgrp or dtg parameters in the SIP request and the call is redirected to either a line/port or a directory number, depending on the value of applyAccessSideRules. When set to "enablePermissive", and if the SIP request has a tgrp or dtg parameter, the policy instance attempts a trunk group lookup. If the lookup fails, route processing continues as if no tgrp or dtg were present. When set to "enableRestrictive", and if the SIP request has a tgrp or dtg parameter, the policy instance attempts a trunk group lookup. If the lookup fails, route processing ends and the Network Server applies the User Not Found treatment.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify an instance of the Originator Redirect policy.

parameter.name: attribute

parameter.name: CallTypes

parameter.name: applyAccessSideRules

parameter.name: supportTrunkGroupLookups
parameter.description: When set to "disable", the policy instance ignores any tgrp or dtg parameters in the SIP request and the call is redirected to either a line/port or a directory number, depending on the value of applyAccessSideRules. When set to "enablePermissive", and if the SIP request has a tgrp or dtg parameter, the policy instance attempts a trunk group lookup. If the lookup fails, route processing continues as if no tgrp or dtg were present. When set to "enableRestrictive", and if the SIP request has a tgrp or dtg parameter, the policy instance attempts a trunk group lookup. If the lookup fails, route processing ends and the Network Server applies the User Not Found treatment.

command.name: delete

parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

context.name: OrigDMI
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Originator Redirect Digit Manipulation Index (OrigDMI) entry-related attributes. When the caller's DN is not in the E.164 format, a digit manipulation index (DMI) allows the manipulation of the caller's DN so that it is transformed to the E.164 format. The DMI is configurable at this level. This context allows configuring a DMI per instance, on a range of DNs (from, to). This DMI substitution is used to redirect a SIP REGISTER or SIP OPTIONS message. For these messages, the caller corresponds to the line/port of a device, which may not correspond to the E.164 format of the user's DN.

context.name: PhysLocation
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Physical Location policy. The purpose of this policy is to find, for a call, a set of routes obtained by simultaneously looking at:The call type of the call, as computed by the CallTyping and/or PreCallTyping policies. The policy does not apply to calls made to URL addresses. So for a call of type "X", PhysLocation only selects routing results that are provisioned with a call type of "X" or with a call type of "ALL".The value contained in the P-Access-Network-Info header of the call's incoming SIP message. This data describes the physical location of the call originator (calling party). So for an incoming call with a P-Access-Network-Info header present, PhysLocation only selects routing results that are provisioned with exactly the same physical location specification (not case sensitive though).By matching the call attributes with the data provisioned in the policy instance, PhysLocation obtains zero or more route results. It then orders them by cost and weight. A route result can be of two types:A new phone number (DN), which replaces the called party number from this point on, and which triggers the Network Server to restart call processing from the beginning. A routing network element (NE) to which the call should be routed. If the set of routes results that PhysLocation obtains, contains at least one DN result, PhysLocation considers that call processing should restart using the DN result as the new called address (if more than one DN result exists in the list, the lowest cost DN is selected).If the set of routes results that PhysLocation obtains, only contains routing NE results, PhysLocation builds an ordered list of contacts (one for each routing NE), stops processing, and sends back a 302 Moved temporarily response. If the set of routes results is empty, PhysLocation does nothing and call processing continues to other policies.

context.name: PreCallTyping
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Pre-Call Typing (PreCallTyping) policy. This policy associates a call type to an incoming call. It operates similarly to Call Typing, the main difference being in the dial plan used to perform the call typing determination. While Call Typing accesses system-wide country code-based dial plans to find the call type for calls, in Pre-Call Typing each policy instance defines its own dial plans. Pre-Call Typing can be used to override some or all results given by Call Typing, in order to bypass country code-based Call Typing when a more specific, instance-based call typing, is needed. In a typical deployment, Call Typing continues to be the primary mechanism to derive call types, with Pre-Call Typing handling special cases or exceptions for some subscribers only.Pre-Call Typing is a public routing policy that can be assigned to any profile, with or without Call Typing. Also, Pre-Call Typing is a multi-instance policy, meaning that more than one Pre-Call Typing policy instance can exist.Dial plan names used in Pre-Call Typing do not need to be pre-provisioned for them to be used in dial plan entries. The dial plan name in a dial plan entry is simply a string that identifies a dial plan. However, the Pre-Call Typing policy, when processing a call, always tries to find a dial plan called "dflt", if the called number is a non-E.164 number. Similarly, Pre-Call Typing always tries to find a dial plan called "dflt_e164", if the called number is an E.164 number. These two names, "dflt" and "dflt_e164", are therefore the entry dial plan names for Pre-Call Typing. Other dial plan names can also be created for the support of the dial plan re-entry functionality.

parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

parameter.name: cc
parameter.description: The country code.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: The name of an attribute to filter on.

parameter.name: dialPlan
parameter.description: The dial plan name.

parameter.name: from
parameter.description: Numbers starting with digits comprised in the range delimited by "from" and "to" are handled by this entry.

parameter.name: to
parameter.description: Numbers starting with digits comprised in the range delimited by "from" and "to" are handled by this entry.

parameter.name: match
parameter.description: Digit matching rules: *exact: The compared digits must match exactly. *suffix: Must match the trailing digits. prefix: Must match the leading digits.

parameter.name: min
parameter.description: Minimum number of digits required in the number being analyzed.

parameter.name: max
parameter.description: Maximum number of digits allowed in the number being analyzed.

parameter.name: callType
parameter.description: The type of call this policy instance can process.

parameter.name: prefix
parameter.description: Number of digits that are considered as prefix digits in the number being analyzed.

parameter.name: action
parameter.description: List of actions that describe the type of call being identified.

parameter.name: alternateCallIndicator
parameter.description: Used in communication between the Application Server and the Network Server to identify if a call is an expensive call. It only appears in the 302 Moved Temporarily message and only if the response is sent to a Hosting NE configured with the CallTypeInfoRequired signaling attribute. It is a list of contact parameters to be added to the response. Each parameter is either a token or a token=value and parameters are separated by semi-colons. Tokens and values can only contain the following characters: A-Z, a-z, 0-9, or : -.!%*_+`'~.The following tokens, which are already known on the Network Server cannot be used: ct, cat, ton, or q. Examples of a valid alternateCallIndicator include:aci=exptoken1;token2=value2;token3.

parameter.name: desc
parameter.description: Description of the purpose of this entry.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add a Dial Plan entry. The entry Dial Plan for non-E.164 numbers is called "dflt", the one for E.164 numbers is called "dflt_e164" and the one for SMS calls is called "dflt_sms".

context.name: PrefixStripping

parameter.name: instance

parameter.name: CallTypes
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the types of calls that this policy instance processes.

context.name: Prefix

parameter.name: ImsPrefix
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS) prefix. The IMS prefix is a sequence of decimal digits (0 through 9) and begins with a plus sign (+).

command.description: This command is used to add a prefix entry.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the name of the instance of this policy.

parameter.name: ImsPrefix
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS) prefix. The IMS prefix is a sequence of decimal digits (0 through 9) and begins with a plus sign (+).

parameter.name: CsPrefix
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the Circuit Switched (CS) prefix. The CS prefix is a sequence of hexadecimals (A-F) and decimal digits (0-9) beginning with a plus sign (+).

parameter.name: ServiceInfo
parameter.description: This parameter specifies service information corresponds to the type of prefix. This information is used for inserting a corresponding SIP uri-parameter into the uppermost Route header to the Application Server.

command.description: This command is used to set a prefix entry.

parameter.name: to

parameter.name: replaceNumber
parameter.description: This parameter specifies the replacment number in E164 format. The field starts with a plus sign (+).

context.name: Profile
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Profile policy. The Network Server processes routing rules according to the call type and the policy instance assigned to the profile for that enterprise or user group. The following describes policies, policy instances, and profiles. Policies. *Routing services are implemented through policies (for example, SubLocation, or Equal Access.). Routing policies specify the routing logic. To implement different routing applications with similar routing logic, a routing policy will have different instances. Policy Instances. *For some policies (for example, Call Screening), a variation can be defined which has the major properties of the policy but some different attributes. Not all policies, however, can have multiple instances. Profiles. *A profile is the assignment of policy instances to enterprises and user groups. A profile consists of one or more instances of different policies. Once a profile is defined, it may be assigned too many enterprises and user groups. Each enterprise and user group can only have one profile. An enterprise must have a profile, but profiles can also be assigned at the user group level. If a profile exists for both a user group and its enterprise, the user group profile has precedence. A system-wide default profile also can be defined. If a caller is unknown, the default profile is used.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the following information for profiles:A list of current profiles. The policy instances assigned to a specific profile. The default profile.

parameter.name: profile
parameter.description: The name of the routing profile.

parameter.name: profile
parameter.description: The name of the routing profile.

parameter.name: default
parameter.description: The default profile policy.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to associate policy instances to a profile or to create a new profile. While more than one policy can be added to a profile, only one instance of any given policy can be used at a time. Profiles are then used by enterprises and user groups for call routing. Policy instances are identified by the combination of their policy and instance names. When adding a policy instance to a profile, instances of other policy types are retained. If the same policy type you are adding already exists for that profile, you first must delete that instance. If the policy instance does not already exists for that profile, the corresponding policy is added to the profile. Policy instances must exist in the system before they can be added to a profile.

parameter.name: profile
parameter.description: The name of the profile.

parameter.name: policy
parameter.description: The name of the new policy.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the profile policy instance.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify the default profile is used when the caller is unknown.

parameter.name: default
parameter.description: The default profile policy.

parameter.name: profile
parameter.description: The name of the profile.

command.name: delete
command.description: This command is used to delete profiles and policy instances. By deleting a policy instance, that policy no longer exists for that profile.

parameter.name: profile
parameter.description: The name of the routing profile.

parameter.name: policy
parameter.description: The policy being included (for example, SubLocation).

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The instance of the policy.

context.name: RCBasedRtg
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Rate Center Based Routing (RCBasedRtg) policy. This policy allows a system provider to select a destination based on the call originator's rate center and call type. This level is used to view, add, delete, or modify an instance of the policy.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view Rate Center Based Routing (RCBasedRtg) instance-related attributes.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add a Rate Center Based Routing (RCBasedRtg) instance.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

parameter.name: Enable
parameter.description: Controls if this policies is enabled or not. When a policy is disabled, it is ignored by the NS during call processing even if assigned.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Additional attributes to include through the add command.

parameter.name: CallTypes
parameter.description: The type of call this policy instance can process.

parameter.name: CicRequiredEnable
parameter.description: Indicates whether CIC information is required in the return route.

parameter.name: CicAlways
parameter.description: When set to "true", the policy instance must always include a CIC parameter in the returned contacts. For this option to take effect, the CICRequiredEnable option must be set to "true".

parameter.name: addCICasCAC
parameter.description: When set to never, no special action is taken by the Network Server regarding the CIC. This is the default value. When set to nsOnly, the Network Server returns the CIC as if it were dialed by the caller. It prepends the called party number with the caller's default carrier prefix followed by the CIC, simply interpreted as a CAC (Carrier Access Code). When set to alwaysIfSub, the Network Server adds the CIC as a CAC if the carrier selection is made by the Network Server or by the Application Server with a subscribed PIC. When set to either nsOnly or alwaysIfSub, it has no impact on URL calls or when the called party number received by the Network Server is a global E.164 number. The CICRequiredEnable option must be set to true for this option to take effect.

parameter.name: keepPrefix
parameter.description: When set to "true", the Network Server returns the prefix provided in the incoming request to translate, as part of the contacts.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify Rate Center Based Routing (RCBasedRtg) instance-related attributes.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Attribute to modify.

parameter.name: Enable
parameter.description: Controls if this policies is enabled or not. When a policy is disabled, it is ignored by the NS during call processing even if assigned.

parameter.name: CallTypes
parameter.description: The type of call this policy instance can process.

parameter.name: CicRequiredEnable
parameter.description: Indicates whether CIC information is required in the return route.

parameter.name: CicAlways
parameter.description: When set to "true", the policy instance must always include a CIC parameter in the returned contacts. This option only applies when CicRequiredEnable is set to "true".

parameter.name: addCICasCAC
parameter.description: When set to never, no special action is taken by the Network Server regarding the CIC. When set to nsOnly, the Network Server returns the CIC as if it were dialed by the caller. It prepends the called party number with the caller's default carrier prefix followed by the CIC, simply interpreted as a CAC (Carrier Access Code). When set to alwaysIfSub, the Network Server adds the CIC as a CAC if the carrier selection is made by the Network Server or by the Application Server with a subscribed PIC. When set to either nsOnly or alwaysIfSub, it has no impact on URL calls or when the called party number received by the Network Server is a global E.164 number.

parameter.name: keepPrefix
parameter.description: When set to "true", the Network Server returns the prefix provided in the incoming request to translate, as part of the contacts.

command.name: delete
command.description: This command is used to delete an existing Rate Center Based Routing (RCBasedRtg) instance.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

context.name: ReverseTranslation
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Reverse Translation policy. This policy converts the remote party number to the configured format based on the call type and the matching DN range of the remote party number. It uses Digit Manipulations defined in the system to do the conversion. Digit Manipulations are linked to Reverse Translation Rules, themselves linked to Reverse Translation Policy Instance. The remote party number in appropriate format is returned as the user-info part of the contact URI in the 302 response.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view Reverse Translation instance-related attributes.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the policy instance to get.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add a Reverse Translation instance.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

parameter.name: Enable
parameter.description: Controls if this policies is enabled or not. When a policy is disabled, it is ignored by the NS during call processing even if assigned.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Additional attributes to include through the add command.

parameter.name: CallTypes
parameter.description: The type of call this policy instance can process.

parameter.name: forceAnswerOnNoMatch
parameter.description: When set to "true", a 302 answer is returned by the ReverseTranslation policy instance even if no rule matches. The 302 answer include the call type, call category, type of network and alternate call indicator as determined by previously applied policies.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify Reverse Translation instance-related attributes.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the policy instance to modify.

parameter.name: attribute

parameter.description: The type of call the rules apply to.

parameter.name: from
parameter.description: Starting point of a DN range the called party DN must belong to for the rules to apply.

parameter.name: to
parameter.description: Ending point of a DN range the called party DN must belong to for the rules to apply.

parameter.name: callCategory
parameter.description: This indicates the category determined by Call Screening, for which the rule applies. Use "ANY" for the rule to apply regardless of the call category value.

parameter.name: alternateCallIndicator
parameter.description: This indicates the alternate call indicator determined by Pre-Call Typing, for which the rule applies. Each parameter is either a token or a token=value and parameters are separated by semi-colons. Tokens and values can only contain the following characters: A-Z, a-z, 0-9, or : -.!%*_+`'~. The following tokens, which are already known on the Network Server, cannot be used: ct, cat, ton, or q. Use an empty string: "" for the rule to apply regardless of the alternate call indicator value. Examples of a valid alternate call indicator include: aci=exptoken1;token2=value2;token3.

parameter.name: dmi
parameter.description: The digit manipulation index reference.

context.name: SIMPLE
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the attributes related to the Session Initiation Messaging and Presence Leveraging Enhancements (SIMPLE) policy. This policy supports communication with MSN/Windows Messenger. It provides a mechanism to process incoming SIP Subscribe and Message messages in order to return a response containing a list of contacts (destinations) that should be able to process the messages. This policy differs from the others by the fact that it is not triggered on SIP INVITE messages but only on SIP Message and Subscribe messages. Therefore, for now, no precedence can be defined because no other policy processes these messages, besides of course the public counterpart of this policy. If the Request URI indicates that the message is for a URL provisioned in the Network Server, the policy redirects this message to the Hosting NE on which the URL is hosted. If the URL is not known in the Network Server, the policy redirects the message to the SIMPLE servers capable to handle traffic for the domain specified in the URL. For example, if the URL is "aaaaa@broadsoft.com", and if gateway provisioning in the policy specifies that "broadsoft.com" messages should be routed to SIMPLE gateway "broad1", then the policy builds a redirect response using the addresses of Resource NE "broad1". Similarly, default SIMPLE gateway addresses are returned for all the Resource NEs provisioned with no specific domain name (meaning these Resource NEs can carry Windows Messenger traffic regardless of the domain name of the recipient).

context.name: SMSDefaultRtg
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the Short Message Service (SMS) Default Routing policy. By default, runs immediately after the SMS Near-End Routing policy. Like the SMS Near-End Routing policy, it processes only MESSAGE requests. The policy selects the destination routingNE based on the MESSAGE request call type. If the DMI field identifies a digit manipulation program, then the policy applies the program to the destination number. If the policy selects more than one destination, then the Network Server applies the Cost and Weight, according to the usual Network Server algorithm, to order the selected destinations. If an entry in the routing table matches, the Network Server proceeds to the Response phase and no additional policies are processed.

parameter.description: Used to order multiple routes. It is used to identify the paths that must always be tried first. When returning a list of network elements, the list is first ordered based on the cost, the network element with the lowest cost being the first entry in the list.

parameter.name: weight
parameter.description: Used to order results using random selection and it is only used if the costs of two or more results are the same in the returned list. In such a case, the weight is used as a probability factor, the higher the weight is relative to the other results; the more chance this result is put ahead in the returned list.

context.name: SMSNearEndRtg
context.description: The SMS Near-End Routing policy processes a MESSAGE request and selects one or more routing destinations based on the number of the originator. The policy selects routing destinations by matching entries in a routing table. The policy may also apply a digit manipulation program to the destination number based on the matching routing table entry. If the originator's number matches the range defined by From and To, and if the call type matches the entry's Call Type, then the policy selects the named Routing NE as a destination. If the DMI field identifies a digit manipulation program, then the policy applies the program to the destination number. If the policy selects more than one destination, then the Network Server applies the Cost and Weight, according to the usual Network Server algorithm, to order the selected destinations. If an entry in the routing table matches, the Network Server proceeds to the Response phase and no additional policies are processed.

context.name: SvcCtrRtg
context.description: The Service Center Routing policy (SvcCtrRtg) is an origination-based routing policy. It allows a Network Server administrator to route incoming calls to specific destinations based on the call originator and on the Network Server-identified call type. This policy uses service routing entries to map incoming call types and originator defined by a range of valid digits to a destination. It provides support for three types of routing results:Fully specified directory number destination (meaning, 11 digits for North America E.164 compliant number)Network gatewaysNetwork gateway controllers along with a destination trunk groupIf a phone or directory number is first obtained from the search in the service routing list, it replaces the service number as the call destination. The call will thereafter be routed using Network Server public routing policies. If gateways and/or gateway controllers are obtained from the search in the service routing list, they are be added as contacts in the SIP 302 response. The call is then routed as is and does not go through other policies. If a trunk group is obtained from the search in the service routing list, a valid BroadWorks contact is added in the SIP 302 response. The user part of the contact contains the address trunkgroup@mgcpGateway (in escaped form) and the host part contains an Application Server acting as a gateway controller. The call is then routed as is and does not go through other policies. For the Service Center Routing policy, a service center routing list is entered to determine how calls are handled.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view Service Center Routing policy attributes.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add an instance of the Service Center Routing policy.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

parameter.name: Enable
parameter.description: Controls if this policies is enabled or not. When a policy is disabled, it is ignored by the NS during call processing even if assigned.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Additional attributes to include through the add command.

parameter.name: CallTypes
parameter.description: The type of call this policy instance can process.

parameter.name: CicRequiredEnable
parameter.description: Indicates whether CIC information is required in the returned route.

parameter.name: CicAlways
parameter.description: When set to "true", the policy instance should always include a CIC parameter in the returned contacts. For this to take effect, the CICRequiredEnable option must be set to "true".

parameter.name: addCICasCAC
parameter.description: When set to never, no special action is taken by the Network Server regarding the CIC. This is the default value. When set to nsOnly, the Network Server returns the CIC as if it were dialed by the caller. It prepends the called party number with the caller's default carrier prefix followed by the CIC, simply interpreted as a CAC (Carrier Access Code). When set to alwaysIfSub, the Network Server adds the CIC as a CAC if the carrier selection is made by the Network Server or by the Application Server with a subscribed PIC. When set to either nsOnly or alwaysIfSub, it has no impact on URL calls or when the called party number received by the Network Server is a global E.164 number. The CICRequiredEnable option must be set to true for this option to take effect.

parameter.name: CicAlways
parameter.description: When set to "true", the policy instance must always include a CIC parameter in the returned contacts. For this to take effect, the CICRequiredEnable option must be set to "true".

parameter.name: addCICasCAC
parameter.description: When set to never, no special action is taken by the Network Server regarding the CIC. When set to nsOnly, the Network Server returns the CIC as if it were dialed by the caller. It prepends the called party number with the caller's default carrier prefix followed by the CIC, simply interpreted as a CAC (Carrier Access Code). When set to alwaysIfSub, the Network Server adds the CIC as a CAC if the carrier selection is made by the Network Server or by the Application Server with a subscribed PIC. When set to either nsOnly or alwaysIfSub, it has no impact on URL calls or when the called party number received by the Network Server is a global E.164 number.

parameter.name: from
parameter.description: Starting point of a DN range the calling party DN must belong to for the route to apply.

parameter.name: to
parameter.description: Ending point of a DN range the calling party DN must belong to for the entry to apply.

parameter.name: callSelector
parameter.description: Route selector: *All: The route applies to all calls regardless of the diversion indicator. *NoRedirect: The route only applies for calls that do not have the diversion indicator. *Redirect: The selected route only applies to call the came in with a diversion indicator.

parameter.name: address
parameter.description: If present, this DN (address) replaces the called party DN.

parameter.name: routingNE
parameter.description: The routing network element name.

parameter.name: trunkGroupID
parameter.description: If present, the call is routed to the gateway controller referenced by this entry. This ID is defined via the Trunk Group sub-menu.

parameter.name: dtg
parameter.description: The Destination Trunk Group selector.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add an entry to the service center routing list of the Service Center Routing policy. The unique Service Center Routing List row number is automatically generated at this time.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

parameter.name: callType
parameter.description: The type of call this policy instance can process.

parameter.name: from
parameter.description: Starting point of a DN range the calling party DN must belong to for the route to apply.

parameter.name: to
parameter.description: Ending point of a DN range the calling party DN must belong to for the entry to apply.

parameter.name: cost
parameter.description: Used to order multiple routes with DN/gateway/trunk group. It is used to identify the paths that must always be tried first. When returning a list of network elements, the list is first ordered based on the cost, the network element with the lowest cost being the first entry in the list.

parameter.name: weight
parameter.description: Used to order results using random selection and it is only used if the costs of two or more results are the same in the returned list. In such a case, the weight is used as a probability factor, the higher the weight is relative to the other results; the more chance this result is put ahead in the returned list.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Additional attributes to include through the add command.

parameter.description: Route selector: *All: The route applies to all calls regardless of the diversion indicator. *NoRedirect: The route only applies for calls that do not have the diversion indicator. *Redirect: The selected route only applies to call the came in with a diversion indicator.

parameter.description: If present, this DN (address) replaces the called party DN.

parameter.description: The routing network element name.

parameter.description: The digit manipulation index reference.

context.name: TandemOverflow
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the attributes related to the Tandem Overflow (TandemOverflow) policy. This policy allows calls destined to an unavailable route (typically an NPA or NPANXX) to be re-routed back to the service provider's existing TDM tandem network. A route is considered unavailable when the route has not been configured or, when configured, the routes are unreachable. The Tandem Overflow policy is used to extend a traditional TDM-based network composed of class 5 switches so that calls between switches can be routed through a managed IP network rather than a TDM tandem network. To provide PRI to SIP interconnectivity, each class 5 switch is fronted with a network gateway. This policy works with the Far-End Routing policy which routes incoming calls to the IP network to the gateways serving the destination number. This policy provides overflow route capability to the Far-End Routing policy. The overflow capability is used when a far-end routing route has been not configured or as a back up when a far-end routing route has been configured. Due to regulations, a service provider can only use this solution for calls for which the service provider is the local or long distance carrier. A service provider configures their class 5 switches to send the calls for which the service provider is the PIC or LPIC to the network gateways. For policy precedence, this policy follows the Far-End Routing policy to ensure that:A call without a result from the Far-End Routing policy is re-routed to the PSTNA call with a result from the Far- End Routing policy has additional contacts returned to the incoming gateway if the destination is unreachable. This policy is an originator-based policy, similar to the Near-End Routing policy, which reuses information from the RoutingNE routing tables to identify an outgoing gateway. This policy also allows a service provider to prefix the outgoing contact with a digit string, for example, a CAC code (101XXXX).

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view the attributes related to the Tandem Overflow (TandemOverflow) policy.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add an instance of the Tandem Overflow policy.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

parameter.name: Enable
parameter.description: Controls if this policies is enabled or not. When a policy is disabled, it is ignored by the NS during call processing even if assigned.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Additional attributes to include through the add command.

parameter.name: CallTypes
parameter.description: The type of call this policy instance can process.

parameter.name: Prefix
parameter.description: Specifies the carrier-specific digit prefixing sequence, for example: 1011234.

parameter.name: Prefix
parameter.description: Specifies the carrier-specific digit prefixing sequence, for example: 1011234.

context.name: TgrpTerm
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the attributed related to the Trunk Group Termination (TgrpTerm) policy. This is used to find the hosting NE associated with the tgrp parameter found in a SIP request. The Hosting NE is obtained from the configured Trunk Group with an identity (Trunk Group Identity or DTG Identity) matching the SIP request tgrp parameter.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view an instance of the Trunk Group Termination (TgrpTerm) policy.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

parameter.name: Enable
parameter.description: Controls if this policies is enabled or not. When a policy is disabled, it is ignored by the NS during call processing even if assigned.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Additional attributes to include through the add command.

parameter.name: CallTypes
parameter.description: The type of call this policy instance can process.

parameter.name: enablePermissiveLookups
parameter.description: This attribute applies when a trunk group matching the tgrp or dtg of the SIP request URI cannot be found. When set to "true", the route processing continues as if no tgrp or dtg is present in the SIP URI. When set to "false", the route processing ends and the User Not Found treatment is applied.

context.name: UrlDialing
context.description: This level is used to view, add, delete, and modify attributes related to the URL Dialing (UrlDialing) routing policy. This policy is a Session Initiation Protocol (SIP)-based policy. Upon URL dialing call origination, the Application Server sends the call of unknown alias to the Network Server. The Network Server then performs a lookup in its table of URLs and tries to identify the subscriber location. When the subscriber is found, a 302 (moved temporarily) is returned to the originating Application Server with the new destination attached. In the case where the subscriber is not found, a 302 is still sent but with the original targeted domain as the new destination.

command.description: This command is used to view an instance of the URL Dialing policy.

parameter.name: instance

parameter.name: instance

parameter.description: Controls if this policies is enabled or not. When a policy is disabled, it is ignored by the NS during call processing even if assigned.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Additional attributes to include through the add command.

parameter.name: CallTypes
parameter.description: The type of call this policy instance can process.

parameter.name: lineportOnly
parameter.description: When set to "true", disables URL Dialing for this URL Dialing policy instance while allowing (lineport) PUI call routing.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify an instance of the URL Dialing policy.

context.name: XSLocation
context.description: This level is used to view and modify the XS Location policy. The XS Location policy allows the Network Server to select an Application Server based on the enterprise/group the user belongs to. The XS Location policy is different from other existing policies in the Network Server because it is a Proxy policy instead of being a Redirect policy. To enable XS Location, the administrator should add the XS Location policy to the S-CSCF Routing Network Element (NE) profile.

command.name: get
command.description: This command is used to view an instance of the XS Location policy.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

command.name: add
command.description: This command is used to add an instance of the XS Location policy.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

parameter.name: Enable
parameter.description: Controls if this policy is enabled or not. When a policy is disabled, it is ignored by the NS during call processing even if assigned.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Additional attributes to include through the add command.

parameter.name: CallTypes
parameter.description: The type of call this policy instance can process. Use ALL.

parameter.name: dataCenterRoutingEnabled
parameter.description: If enabled, the routing results that the policy obtains are re-ordered such that all the routes going to the servers located in the same data center as the Network Server node appear first in the list of routes. The default value is false.

parameter.name: mobileLocationLookupEnabled
parameter.description: If enabled, the policy performs lookup for the originator or terminator of the call from the mobile DN database.

parameter.name: networkVoicePortalLookupEnabled
parameter.description: If enabled, the policy performs lookup for the next System Voice Portal (SVP) from the round-robin list of SVPs that are configured to support the Network Voice Portal number.

command.name: set
command.description: This command is used to modify an instance of the XS Location policy.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.

parameter.name: attribute
parameter.description: Attribute to modify.

parameter.name: Enable
parameter.description: Controls if this policy is enabled or not. When a policy is disabled, it is ignored by the NS during call processing even if assigned.

parameter.name: CallTypes
parameter.description: The type of call this policy instance can process. Use ALL.

parameter.name: dataCenterRoutingEnabled
parameter.description: If enabled, the routing results that the policy obtains are re-ordered such that all the routes going to the servers located in the same data center as the Network Server node appear first in the list of routes. The default value is false.

parameter.name: mobileLocationLookupEnabled
parameter.description: If enabled, the policy performs lookup for the originator or terminator of the call from the mobile DN database.

parameter.name: networkVoicePortalLookupEnabled
parameter.description: If enabled, the policy performs lookup for the called number from the network voice portal database.

command.name: delete
command.description: This command is used to delete an instance of the XS Location policy.

parameter.name: instance
parameter.description: The name of the instance for this policy.
